sime.tcp

Class Segment

  • java.lang.Object
    • sime.Packet
      • sime.tcp.Segment
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Cloneable, java.lang.Comparable<Segment>

    public class Segment
extends Packet
implements java.lang.Comparable<Segment>
    TCP segment, which could carry either data, ACK, or both.
    Note that this class implements java.lang.Comparable so that TCP segments can be compared (and sorted) by their sequence number.
    Author:
    Ivan Marsic

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description

      Acknowledgment sequence number, in case this segment also acknowledges received data.

      boolean isAck
      A flag that informs whether or not this segment contains an ACK.
      (package private) int ordinalNum
      Ordinal number of this segment.
      (package private) int ordinalNumAck
      Similar to ordinalNum
      int rcvWindow
      The size of the currently available space in the receiver's buffer (used mostly for buffering out-of-order segments).
      int timestamp
      The sending time of a segment (similar to the timestamp option in the Options field of an actual TCP header).

    • Field Detail

      • ackSequenceNumber

        public int ackSequenceNumber
        Acknowledgment sequence number, in case this segment also acknowledges received data. This number is valid only if the isAck flag is set isAck.

      • dataSequenceNumber

        public int dataSequenceNumber
        Sequence number of this segment, which is the sequence number of the first byte of data carried in this segment.

      • isAck

        public boolean isAck
        A flag that informs whether or not this segment contains an ACK.

      • ordinalNum

        int ordinalNum
        Ordinal number of this segment. This is only for tracking purposes and this field is not present in actual TCP segments.
        Note: The value is computed assuming that dataSequenceNumber starts at zero.

      • ordinalNumAck

        int ordinalNumAck
        Similar to ordinalNum

      • rcvWindow

        public int rcvWindow
        The size of the currently available space in the receiver's buffer (used mostly for buffering out-of-order segments).
        See Also:
        Receiver.rcvBuffer

      • timestamp

        public int timestamp
        The sending time of a segment (similar to the timestamp option in the Options field of an actual TCP header). See RFC 1323, Section 3.2 TCP Timestamps Option.
        The corresponding acknowledgment segment should bounce the same value.

        In fact, there should be two timestamps per segment, if acknowledgments are piggybacked on data segments, but in this simulator we assume that all acknowledgments are zero-data segments (i.e., they don't have any payload.

        This field should be set to -1 if the segment is a retransmitted segment, and no RTT estimation should be performed for retransmitted segments.

    • Constructor Detail

      • Segment

        public Segment(NetworkElement destinationAddr_,
       int rcvWindow_,
       int ackSeqNum_)
        Constructor for acknowledgment-only segments (zero data payload).
        Parameters:
        rcvWindow_ - the current receive window size of the sender of this segment
        ackSeqNum_ - the acknowledgment sequence number of this segment

      • Segment

        public Segment(NetworkElement destinationAddr_,
       int rcvWindow_,
       int seqNum_,
       byte[] dataPayload_)
        Constructor for data-only segments.
        Parameters:
        rcvWindow_ - the current receive window size of the sender of this segment
        seqNum_ - the sequence number for the data payload.
        dataPayload_ - the data payload contained in this segment

      • Segment

        public Segment(NetworkElement destinationAddr_,
       int rcvWindow_,
       int seqNum_,
       byte[] dataPayload_,
       int ackSeqNum_)
        Constructor for both data and acknowledgment segments, i.e., an acknowledgment is piggybacked on a data segment going to the same destination.
        Parameters:
        rcvWindow_ - the current receive window size of the sender of this segment
        seqNum_ - the sequence number of this segment
        dataPayload_ - the data payload, if any
        ackSeqNum_ - the acknowledgment sequence number, if any

    • Method Detail

      • compareTo

        public int compareTo(Segment anotherSegmentToCompareTo_)
        This method is part of the java.lang.Comparable interface. Lists (and arrays) of objects that implement this interface can be sorted automatically by java.util.Collections.sort() ( and java.util.Arrays.sort() ).

        Such capability is needed by the TCP receiver module when filling the gaps in the sequence numbers of received segments.

        Specified by:
        compareTo in interface java.lang.Comparable<Segment>
        See Also:
        Receiver.checkBufferedSegments()

      • setAckSequenceNumber

        public void setAckSequenceNumber(int ackSequenceNumber_)
        Attribute setter for the acknowledgment sequence number. Defined because Receiver.handle(Segment) resets the ACK sequence number for cumulative ACKs, but then we need to recompute ordinalNumAck as well.
        Parameters:
        ackSequenceNumber_ - the acknowledgment sequence number to set

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Prints out some basic information about this TCP segment. It is used mostly for reporting/debugging purposes. This method is part of the java.lang.Object interface.
        Overrides:
        toString in class Packet
